pros: Great work! Everyone is very professional.
cons: There are no cons at this time.

pros: There wasn't many pros at this location. Everything was disorganized, no work flows in place and when you brought anything clinical to managements attention they would just give you a blank stare and say "oh really, I didn't know that". Example: when I started working there the first week I had to tell the Lead MA and another MA including the manager that we LEGALLY HAVE TO GIVE OUT VIS forms when administering an immunization to patients. The manager had no clue what I was talking about and the the MA'S stated that patients don't want them and that it is not illegal if we don't hand them out. My mind was blown!!!!
cons: I listed cons in with the pros, if there was any!

pros: Caring people, great manager, flexible schedule
cons: Department was shut down and manager who was a long time employee was laid off with little notice

pros: Stable job opportunity with this company

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Portland, OR

review_title: A very enjoyable place to work
job_title: Human Resource Representative in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
The small size of Tuality means that people know each other and change is really possible. From my first day, I was encouraged to give feedback and suggest improvements as I saw them. People are generally friendly and familiar with each other - I was surprised how often my coworkers know others by name. 

The onboarding process was incredibly smooth and easy, they really made me feel prepared. Everybody goes through a two-day (paid) orientation to get started, which I appreciated as somebody who had never worked in a hospital setting before. 

There is also a great connection with and commitment to the community this hospital is in. Regular emails about what is going on in the area make me feel in-touch with the world outside the hospital. And, employees get discounted movie tickets, sports game tickets, zoo tickets, etc.

Employee health initiatives (hydration challenge, wellness punch cards) are amazing! There is a great focus on employee wellness and keeping people healthy and happy.
cons: Working in the HR department has been incredibly busy and chaotic at times with the new affiliation with OHSU and all of the changes that entails. I enjoy being busy, but recognize that the HR department could use more hands. (The Pro to this is all the people working in the HR department are diligent, hardworking people that I have been proud to work with!)

pros: The People are very nice
cons: Its a very small hospital

pros: strong teams--I love the staff in my department and hospital wide, most people seem to.  My personal boss allows a lot of freedom to do your job and to bring process changes to him.
cons:
Pay--if you are non-clinical be prepared to make about 25% less than you would anywhere else.  
Instability--A lot of changes with the "partnership" with OHSU; some good to allow the company to be more lean and allow for growth of service lines, others are just letting our evil overlords call the shots without any support. 
Low morale--Partnership agreement has meant jobs cut/departments dissolved with little to no warning.

job_title: If Named My Job Title, Would Give Away Identity in Hillsboro, OR
pros: I was well paid.  I was mostly appreciated by upper management.
cons: The turnover for my department (mostly nurses, but other professionals as well) was the worst I have seen in 25 years in the industry.  Retention efforts were very poor.  I left a year or so ago.  Since I left nearly every position has turned over, with a couple of remaining employees hanging by a thread.  Decreased retention leads to increased work load on remaining staff, and increased burnout.  Every time.  This is not a new concept.  If you are interviewing at Tuality, ask about turnover in the department you are interviewing for.

pros: Community hospital (formerly), lots of good people (most of whom have left or are leaving)
cons:
Avoid this employer at all costs.  The toxic environment is unhealthy and damaging.. The dysfunction starts at the top, with a tyrannical CEO who rules with fear and distrust.  After destroying this small community hospital, she’ll probably move on, voluntarily or involuntarily but it might be too late.  

Top management demands agreement and wants to hear everything is done according to OHSU wishes, but she’s above the basic rules of leadership (respect, courtesy and trust).  Long-term managers are systematically run out to bring in loyalists, most of who acknowledge they are just passing through or working at THC to “gain experience”, because they don’t have any when they were hired.

Most employees,  providers included, are looking for other jobs.  If you want a short-term gig until a decent job becomes available, this is the place for you.  Otherwise, my best advice is keep looking.

pros:
I worked at Tuality Community Hospital







 

Doesn't Recommend



 

Negative Outlook




















Pros

None, some nice coworkers and cafeteria food is decent (if you even get to eat). Decent location.
cons:
Cons

Deplorable working conditions, such as dangerously short staffing, unsafe practices, scary facilities, no meals/breaks, Draconian workplace, incompetent do nothing out of touch management, high employee turnover, and could put patients in harm's way. There is very little use of support staff (CNA's) if you even get one then they have to cover the entire floor, so the bulk of the work is on the RN's. These deplorable conditions contribute to a very high stress environment that leads to a poor culture of the environment resulting in passive aggressive workplace hostility. Politics among upper management are underhanded. The ED is even more horrific if you can believe that. This hospital puts patients at risk and puts RNs' licenses at risk as well. Poor pay and out of touch policies. This facility has had to resort to hiring new RN's, as experienced RN's avoid this place. To say it is like walking into the 1970's is being kind. Do not walk, RUN!

review_title: Dysfunctions grow exponentially under OHSU control.
pros:
It’s tough to be a Small Healthcare provider in today’s environment. It’s even tougher if you’re under the control of a myopic, anachronistic skinflint that micromanaged everyone except the bumbling, incoherent CCO. OHSU keeps proclaiming this is an “affiliation” and that Tuality is an independent entity, but OHSU covers the shared bottom line, so who is really in charge?

This is all a ruse to eliminate the long term, local employees, absconding their benefits and relinquishing control of a Hillsboro institution to the bureaucracy on the hill. The invading horde from OHSU have no regard for Tuality staff or patients and couldn’t manage their way out of an emesis trough with directions on the rim. 

The Tuality good old boy network - specifically the bumbling clods on the board - created this mess, and now the employees, and by extension, the patients of Hillsboro, must pay the price.
cons: Abysmal leadership for the last ten years. OHSU puppet, without the benefits of being a real partner, now.

review_title: Beware, Tuality Community Hospital is a wolf in sheeps clothing.
pros: Small facility that provides services to the local community.
cons: The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing.  Terrible communication and poor follow through on plans. Disrespect  and lack of recognition for employees, especially long term dedicated ones. Dollars spent to bring in consults for improvement, then little or no change. Wrong persons in leadership. Some smaller department having difficulty with time off due to unwillingness to provide adequate staff support. Physician recruiter lacks understanding of actual services provided by facility leading to recruiting useless medical staff. New staff poorly trained and place on the job too soon to cover problems with staffing. Many staff persons over worked.

pros: Very community driven and patient care focused, staff is passionate about their contributions and serving needs, smaller size hospital where you can see your individual impact and have your voice heard.  I personally have felt empowered in my tenure to be able to make a difference here!
cons: At times staffing levels have felt lean

pros: Friendly staff.. flexibility with work.
cons: There had been a leadership change and revealed to employees that they are loosing a lot of money.. that is why they partnered with ohsu. They are becoming more corporate and caring less about patients. Benefits for more than yourself are not worth it.

review_title: Pathetic benefits and pay.  Incompetent administration gives themselves bonuses, employees and patients suffer.
pros: Very small, community-based nonprofit organization.  Some departments are tight knit and supportive of each other.  Management generallly flexible about time off.  Tuition assistance available.
cons:
-There is a huge dissonance in pay between it and other local hospitals.
-Benefits are HORRIBLE.  Most people go through spouses' insurance if they can.
-Every single department has outdated medical equipment.  Computers are 10 years old.
-Morale is low, there is an inferiority complex throughout because no one can say they are proud to work there.
-Minuscule opportunity for advancement.
-The organization's resources few and far between.  
-Lack of respect for employees.

pros: Smaller community hospital with potential to transfer within the organization. Decent benefits. Relationship with OHSU may perhaps be the best thing going for Tuality. I anticipate it will be absorbed at some point.
cons: Administration would like to think they are transparent and in touch with their employees, but in reality there is an underlying fear of reprisal for speaking out. Critical information for making decisions about whether or not the organizations decisions are in your best interest is withheld. Unsure how the relationship with OHSU will unfold.

pros: Tuality offers semi-competitive pay and decent cafeteria food. Parking is easy. Some people are very nice and will help you. It's a small hospital so you get to know everyone.
cons: Pay is less than most hospitals and sometimes the office politics is too much. The hours are long in the pharmacy. Usually a 10 hour shift with a half hour lunch.

job_title: Nurse Case Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: None - Its a nightmare!!
cons:
If you love to work under management who uses passage aggressive behavior and intimidation this is the place for you.  Management prides itself on the "iron fist style".  They regularly  lie, bully and are condescending/mean to employees.  I saw my coworkers cry and come to work everyday in fear of being fired.  Their policies include - you are not allowed to talk to coworkers and you have to use one specific time clock (just 2 examples of many iron fist rules).  The COO has no idea what the people under her actually do on a day to day basis. She endorses bulling by her management by ignoring it. She is the most untrustworthy person I have ever met. Disorganization is the way of Tuality Health Alliance. The management regularly breaks its own rules. For example - they do not wok a 40 hour week (though they make sure you do!!), they take an hour or more for lunch, they wear yoga pants (not policy clothing). 
They are unsupportive and if they see you talking to a coworker anywhere in the building the assume you are a "troublemaker" and you become a target.  Targeting of employees is regular practice.  Its a sad hostile environment, and HR knows, but nothing is done. in my short time here I saw 4 people fired, and there are only 23 employees.  They are management heavy, 5 managers for 23 people, so they have plenty of time to pick on people. 
I have never been so glad to quit a job.  Everyday was filled with dread. Please do yourself a favor, DO NOT WORK HERE!!

pros: My salary was actually good, but the benefits were very expensive and not better than anywhere else making take home pay much less than anticipated.
cons: There was a department meeting my first week on the job to discuss the Employee Survey.  The employees were very unhappy with their jobs.  I can see why.Management is poor and lacks experience.   Policies are ignored or used only to the benefit of the company.  Human Resources while appearing outwardly considerate to employees is not.  They do not abide by their policies.

pros: Environment and the team at Tuality are great. My manager is always   helpful and supportive. We are a not for profit organization so we are financially conservative but our purpose in the community is so important. People are very cooperative and friendly.
cons: Face pace environment which can bring some stress.

pros: Small hospital. Great nurses. Great training.
cons: Upper management is all about numbers. They are not concerned with nurse to patient ratios. They hire lower management who are all about control and not the employees.

job_title: Patient Services Representative in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The small size means you kind of know everybody, at least enough to say hi in passing. Great cafeteria food.
cons: Poor improvement processes. Nobody wants to change procedures. High turnover. HR only helps Tuality- not the employee.

pros: Caring and helpful place to work.
cons: Typical issues with a non profit company. Nothing major so far.

review_title: THC is a hospital-based, not-for-profit, independent, community-governed healthcare system.
pros: THC is ranked number 7 in Oregon for healthiest employer.
cons: Employee's premium health insurance is high.  Not competitive salary.

pros: Small company. Easy to get to know many people.
cons: This company is in transition due to  it's recent affiliation with OHSU.   To wallaby has had a lot to overcome in terms of its community reputation. The recent affiliation hopefully will help but that remains to be seen.

review_title: Tuality WAS a wonderful place to work... CEO needs to go
pros: Small community hospital, employees are all kind and helpful.
cons: Low wages, always short staffed, Overtime is rarely approved.

pros: Small hospital, pay per hour.
cons: Always felt like an “outsider”.  Not welcomed by current employees d/t per diem status and “union” employees disliked me being there taking “their” hours.

pros: It took a long time to get used to being there and once I did it wasn't too bad
cons: It was a long drive from my house. This was my only con though.

pros: Fair compensation and good benefits
cons: Taken over by OHSU so has lost some of the qualities that made it a good place to work.

pros:
Focused on quality of care, cares about the people that work there and is committed to the 
community
cons: Salaries are very competitive and they are keeping up with other hospitals.
